item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Upload your assignment to the Blackboard link for Assignments by Feb 21. Tasks Produce your own original examples of: a deductively valid, sound argument a deductively valid argument which is not sound an inductively strong argument a version of that same argument which is even stronger an argument which sounds a little plausible and might actually persuade someone not being careful about their reasoning, but which is neither deductively valid nor inductively strong Use your imagination and powers of observation a bit: What are some different ways inductive arguments can have more inductive strength than others?

item.title: Interpreting Grades
item.description: This note about grading and interpreting grades just adds some detail to what the course syllabus already says about grading. 4-point scale Grades in this course are assigned and calculated using Hofstra’s 4-point scale (described here in the Hofstra Bulletin). Following the Bulletin, the alphabetical grades, including plus (+) and minus (–), have the following 4-point scale values (and vice versa): letter 4pt Student’s academic performance … A 4.
